I'm in a good mood today. Come and give me a negative review
I played Genshin Impact this morning and brushed the relics five times, but nothing good came out, so I came to give a bad comment
I played three Valorants this morning, all of which were losers, so I came to give a negative review
I played a sparrow soul mahjong this morning, almost unparalleled among the national elite, and I got a bad review for it
This morning, I played the Blue Files and didn't draw any cards, so I came to give a negative review
I woke up this morning and found out that the Shining Youjun girl had not yet taken the public beta, so I came to give a negative review
This morning, I was playing the Star Dome Railway and didn't draw a card, so I came to give a negative review
However, it wasn't until this morning when I hit the Watchman Pioneer 2 that I didn't feel as good as __.

Overwatch 2 is a fantastic game and a great PvP Shooter.
At least have some respect for us that bought your game when it came out early days and give us co-op missions free!

I can't in the right mind recommend anyone play or even try Overwatch 2.

The sole reason that Blizzard released a second game and advertised the game around -- the PvE with progression systems to provide replay value -- was ultimately scrapped. Sure, they eventually released some missions, but it seems like it will be a pay-as-you-go system for missions likely of questionable quality given how the game has been handled so far. This left us with a poorly balanced husk of a game, released only to enforce a new monetization scheme that is so predatory and unfair to players' time that players ended up preferring the previous system of loot boxes.

The claim that the new game brought a "new look" with a "new engine" are entirely false; Overwatch 1 was removed from BattleNET store to hide that Overwatch 2 is the exact same game, on the exact same engine; so much so that for multiple weeks after it's release, it was recognized by SEVERAL applications e.g. Windows Control Panel, NVidia GEForce Experience, and Discord as the exact same game as Overwatch 1. The inclusion of changing environmental settings within maps and claiming it's in any way new technology is laughable; Garry's Mod has had entities to change the position of the sun in the skybox, alongside sky and fog design, which would also dynamically change the maps' lighting -- since before Overwatch 1's original TEASER TRAILER RELEASED. A forum post of players asking how to use these dates back to February 2 of 2014 -- the teaser was November 7.

Unlocking the shiny new heroes is locked behind a battle pass, deep enough in that it could take a couple weeks to unlock them. Alternatively cough up $10 and receive a single hero immediately. In the case of multiple heroes released such as Junker Queen, Sojourn, and Kiriko -- who have all been essential picks since their inception, topping pick rates in most elo ratings (especially higher) due to the versatility and power of their kit -- this means you either spend weeks lulling behind other players or choking up the $10 per character to be able to play the competitive mode viably.

Even if you don't care for the competitive modes, the almost non-existent gameplay style gap between the competitive mode and all other gamemodes -- including any of the modes in Arcade -- results in all casual modes eventually becoming filled with players who want to play to win but are either unhappy with their performance in the competitive mode or want to avoid the stigma behind it, often making even casual play a toxic slog.

There are no deeper mechanics to learn aside from aim and gamesense, which all first person shooters demand regardless. Even the most difficult heroes have kits that can easily be described in a couple sentences per ability maximum. The most intricate details possible are specific interactions between various abilities -- but those aren't mechanics to improve your skill upon, those are knowledge checks that are one-and-done, easily learnable and digestible within seconds.

--
Contrast this with FOUR similar games (2 FPS and 2 traditional MOBAs):

FPS:
Paladins:
- Has deeper mechanics to tinker and learn with talents, card decks, and progressive item purchases within matches
- Competitive mode doesn't allow players to swap character mid-match, making character picks more meaningful
- Competitive mode also features a ban phase commonly found in literally all other competitively viable games

Team Fortress 2:
- Has deeper mechanics to practice and master with blast jumping, surfing, and air strafing
- Bustling community scene with a functional server browser and well-documented modding tools
- Community-supported competitive scene is still alive and well to this day

Traditional MOBAs:
- Items, progressive power increase, strategic downtime, macro play
- Competitive and casual modes feature ban phases
- Characters are locked past pick phase

DOTA 2:
- All characters are free! Wow! Crazy!
- Powerful items allow clever purchases to turn the tide of a bad game
- Mostly unit-cast abilities and items makes effective ranges consistent to play around and more fair
- Slow pace shifts focus more towards macro (gamesense and strategy) play

League of Legends:
- Massive roster supports a wide range of playstyles
- Runes, summoner spells, items, and interactions all within grants tinkering power
- Mostly missile-based abilities grants skill expression through the pushing of character limits
- Fast pace shifts focus more towards micro (mechanics and execution) play

And would you believe, all of these games are free too?
Don't waste your disk space or time, Overwatch 2 doesn't respect it.

MÃ¡s que recomendar el juego, lo que recomiendo es PROBARLO, por que por muy raro que suene, de verdad que este juego no es para todos. Si soportas este juego eres un desequilibrado mental, ya sea por que ya lo eras cuando lo empezaste a jugarlo, o el juego te convirtiÃ³ en eso.

Antes que nada, aclarar que tengo 350+ Horas en Battle.net, como 30 en Nintendo Switch y como 15 en PS4, asi que pueden inferir que me gusta el juego y por ende no tengo derechos humanos.

El juego como tal es bastante solido. Un muy buen juego arruinado por la avaricia y la incompetencia de quienes estÃ¡n detrÃ¡s de el.

El juego no es ni Pay 2 Win , como usuario gratuito puedes disfrutar del juego casi que en toda su totalidad (solÃ­a ser en su totalidad, pero 15 bolas por 3 misiones de historia cambia las cosas, que genio que sos Blizzard). Eso si, el juego si se esfuerza en dejarte en claro, de forma muy descarada, todo lo que te pierdes si no pagas 3 riÃ±ones, pero si quieres simplemente vivir el entorno PvP y competitivo pues tecnicamente nada te detiene, aparte de tener que desbloquear los personajes. Los personajes pueden ser comprados o desbloqueados jugando (algunos ya vienen desbloqueados obvio), lo cual puede ser una molestia por que muchos personajes se hacen counter entre si, y puede suceder que muchas veces la estrategia mÃ¡s optima sea usar un personaje que no tienes, ni mucho menos controlas. Entre eso y que a nivel de jugabilidad es muy variado y se llega a alejar bastante de otros First Person Shooters, es normal que tus primeras horas en este juego sean mÃ¡s frustrantes que divertidas, pero creo que ironicamente es lo que demuestra si el juego es o no para ti. Esa frustraciÃ³n no se va a ir nunca, a veces tu equipo es una mierda y no puedes hacer nada al respecto, a veces ideas una estrategia solida con tu ulti solo para que una habilidad defensiva cualquiera te arruine los planes, a veces todo juega en contra de ti. Los que jugamos y amamos este juego lo hacemos pese a eso (para algunos enfermitos es justamente por eso). 

Todo esto, sin hablar de la multitud de problemas que tiene el juego y que definitivamente no son parte de como fue diseÃ±ado, pero eso es algo con lo que la comunidad pelea constantemente, y si decides unirte a ella ya decidiras si romperte la cabeza con cada mala decisiÃ³n de Blizzard o encogerte de hombros, pensar "it is what it is" y jugar mientras tu alma llora por todo lo que el juego puede ser y no es por que los de Blizzard son tremendos tragap1jas.

Si, quisiera que el juego fuera mÃ¡s divertido y accesible, y menos frustrante y descarado, y sepa judas si eso pasarÃ¡ algÃºn dia, y si hoy juegas a esto y lo primero que piensas es que el juego es una mierda, lo comprendo perfectamente.

Pero es gratis. Pruebalo, mira si tienes la tolerancia para soportar que te chupe el alma, y si te gusta, pues bienvenido al quinto circulo del infierno. Si no te gusta, vienes a insultar a los idiotas blizzard como todos y no pierdes nada. Bueno, un pedazo de vida quizÃ¡, pero tu y yo sabemos que si te planteaste tan siquiera descargar este juego, entonces no ibas a hacer nada de provecho con ese tiempo de todas maneras

A legitimate tragedy of a game.
Incredible art, characters created by incredibly talented artists and and voiced by incredible VAs, genuinely inspiring map design, and sometimes heroes that are genuinely fun to play, all put into a septic tank of a game with baffling balance, 8 billion particles, sources of healing that are impossible to track, all made by a company ran by serial abusers.
This game is a piece of trash

OW2 Is like eating your favourite pizza cold, sure all the essentials are there but itâ€™s stale old and youâ€™ll probably get sick if you try to enjoy it

I have almost 1000 hours in OW and I can say while the game has its moments and flaws it is still one of the best FPS games I have ever played. You can tell that the development, animation, and art team really do love this game and its universe. Its just super unlucky that executives at Blizzard do not care about the players and only want money. I do still recommend playing Overwatch even if the monetization is bad. If you don't want to buy stuff or don't like the skin prices than dont give Blizzard your money. Overwatch can feel extremely rewarding and be so fun with a group of friends. Trust me and give it a shot. GREETINGS
